comments.commentBody:
Rima, I agree with every word you wrote at 12:05 Eastern but still early in Mission Viejo, and I hope every Comment reader will read your words at least twice and then stop and reflect on them.

You write "Do we want to be a truly egalitarian society" and I answer "Yes, Rima Regas, I want to be part of that 'we', and here is a step that President Obama can take in his second term when he is free of worrying about re-election."

He can put in a call to Dorothy Roberts, Professor of Law and Sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, self described as black in common with the President, and author of a brilliant book I have named many times in comments.

The President can say to Dorothy, "Hi Dorothy, I have just read the dedication in your book in which you thank your parents for teaching you that there is only one race, the human race." So yes, Dorothy, it is time for me to state to my people, the American people, a people of extraordinary genetic diversity, that the government will no longer divide us following practice invented to justify slavery and discrimination, classification by fatally invented races."

We are a nation of extraordinary individuals united in a belief in the freedom to be just that, a Rima Regas, a Barack Obama, a Dorothy Roberts who can unite to make life better for those less fortunate than we have been.

Larry Lundgren Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

Should our president get reelected, equality and ethics, in all of their meanings and implications, should be the guiding principles for all of his policies and any bills he signs.

At the foundation of most, if not all, of the problems we are having as a nation, lay philosophical questions. What is the purpose of government? Do we want to be a truly egalitarian society? Will we remain true to the founding principles of our nation and keep religion separate from government? Will we continue to resolve conflicts militarily, or will we lead through diplomacy? Will we reaffirm our commitment to the social contract and adhere to it? Will we repair our economy and lay a strong foundation for a better future for our children?

You're right, Roger, Barack Obama is more likely to make smart decisions than his opponent. More importantly, and hopefully, President Obama has shown us again and again that he is thoughtful of all of us, not some of us.
Dr. Abramovich, I literally cannot understand your post.  What on earth does "And so were saying another failed prez fans in November 1980" possibly mean?

How can a "true democracy" reflect the will of the people when you force your citizens to vote? Sounds more to me like "enforced political participation." We here value individual freedom a bit more than that. Don't get me wrong, I think that the voting methods should be streamlined and standard from state to state. But don't come in here trumpeting that Australia is a "true democracy" when you probably don't know enough about the details of American electoral politics to make such a sweeping judgment.

Also, the framers of the US constitution didn't intend for the united states to be a "one man, one vote" society. The idea of direct democracy scared them to death -- they didn't want the unwashed masses dictating policy. Hence, we have the electoral college and federalism. I don't think either of those institutions are perfect, but you can't criticize the United States for not being a "real democracy, like Australia" because it's like comparing apples to oranges.
Apple has moved all its assembly jobs to China. Romney must've told them to do that!

It frightens me how many people in this supposedly advanced society are ignorant enough to believe all the lies told by Romney and his super PACs, and my kudos to Chrysler for calling him out on the one about moving Jeep jobs to China, but there have been so many others and he gleefully moves along making up more "stuff" without retribution.
What really amazes me about Romney is how smarmy and slimy he is, how outright phony and gaffe-prone. It's hard to imagine people and companies having confidence in a person like this and entrusting millions/billions of dollars to him. Personally, I wouldn't buy a toaster from him.
The media is too busy right now.

"For the third time in the last four presidential campaigns, the Democratic and Republican presidential nominees went into Election Day close in the national polls, with not one of the major opinion surveys giving President Obama or Mitt Romney a lead of statistical significance."

Perhaps, but that doesn't mean it will be close. As Paul Krugman has pointed out, individual polls may have a margin of error of, say 3%, but that doesn't mean that if they all agree, the margin of error is 3%. Nearly all the polls show Obama winning, but within their own margin of error. And Romney knows this -- why else would he be acting so desperate?

The data publicly available makes it easy to go out on a limb and predict it will be decided early. Not a landslide, but a decisive victory.

The winner will appoint at least 2 Supremos and that could make a difference.  What about student loans, a woman's right to choose?  Then there is health care...You can take the attitude that it doesn't matter but that is apathy.

and the winners are BIG BANKS, BIG PHARMA, BIG INSURERS,  BIG MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL!   Obama or Romney?  Both are minions of the establishment and do as they are told.  The two parties are equally responsible for destroying our economy and way of life.  The "American dream" has become a nightmare for tens of millions.

the only person to use racial slurs has been vice president joe biden when he stated that republicans would "put ya'll back in chains" to an audience made up mostly of african americans.
it is ironic to watch liberals cheer as the obama campaign employs the divisive politics of karl rove. the very politics of separation and hate that obama rev 2008 specifically ran against. so much for hope and change.

Sophia, it IS trying, and trying its darndest. How else can we account for the coordinated appearance of various voter suppression laws in so many GOP controlled states?  The question is not whether the GOP is trying, its whether it gets away with it.

They ARE trying to steal this election. It is mind boggling that the US has such an arcane system of voting for the federal office. And that such election fraud is not addressed by the media like NYT. AND that the electoral theft is purely done by the GOP, it is not "equally divided" as the MSM try to portray our political "process."

I am praying the GOP doesn't try to steal another election. As it is the attempts at voter suppression are appalling. This is Third World stuff, not American.

We have got to decide, finally, to accept the fact that not all Americans are Christian, we're not all straight white men and that this is a good thing. We're a nation of immigrants, people from all over the world, of all colors and nationalities, and this diversity is beautiful, not something to suppress or be ashamed of.

Looking at the crowds at Obama events one is struck by the beautiful rainbow of people, living proof of our multifaceted heritage.

Romney's entire campaign has been dogged by racism, what amount to outright threats against workers from their bosses - at his instigation - and full on lies the likes of which I can't remember since Nixon, only Romney and Ryan are arguably worse.

If those two win I'm going to cry. We have a good President, a competent administration, and the reactionary policies of the GOP are outright frightening.

Paul Ryan said today that President Obama doesn't reflect "Judeo-Christian" values. This is yet another slur against a man whose major crime seems to be that he is African-American. We've had years of this malarkey - insults to his face - demands to see his birth certificate and his college grades. It's shameful.

I pray that America votes to keep moving forward, toward hope, away from darkness and fear.

Doug, I'm with CityBumpkin on this one.  I dislike and distrust pretty much everything about Romney; but if he wants to squeeze in some last-minute stumping today, I don't know of any rules against it, so, whatever.

@CityBumpkin It's traditional for candidates to go to their hometown to wait on the election results and to refrain from campaigning on election day. Just as it's been tradition for candidates to release at least five years of tax return.

Romney seems to believe that usual rules don't apply to him.
A tradition is not a 'rule.'

I understand Romney will be campaigning in Ohio on election day. That alone says something about the man who would do (or say) anything to get elected. Then again, with all the monied interests directing his every move, he may not have any say in the matter. Is this who we want leading our country?

Just asking the question.

Keep taking churches and faith based orginizations out of the picyure and it will continue to get worse. Oh, and institute "Shall Carry" laws. If you arm the victim, the thug has to think twice before he acts.

But nope, it won't happen because "that's not PC".

Hand outs will not save them. Teach them, show them. Words are just that: words.

Also, prosecuting the violent thugs without mercy and NO time off for good behaviour will help jail become a deterrent again, instead of a Rite Of Passage.

Why did Republicans conveniently ignore Bush’s gross negligence in regard to the events leading up to 9/11, the worst terrorist attack in our nation’s history? Benghazi pales in comparison.

Bush was repeatedly warned by top CIA officials about the danger that Bin Laden posed, suspicious activity at a flight school should have raised red flags, and the warning of the August 6, 2001 presidential daily brief, “Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S.” was ignored.

Instead, the administration was focused on starting a war of choice in Iraq based on lies.

The Deafness Before the Storm
http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/11/opinion/the-bush-white-house-was-deaf-...

“Could the 9/11 attack have been stopped, had the Bush team reacted with urgency to the warnings contained in all of those daily briefs? We can’t ever know. And that may be the most agonizing reality of all.”
You must be talking about all the ballots that military voters failed to receive.

I wouldn't consider 30 old except maybe at running back. Even in the defensive backfield, NFL players like Ed Reed, Charles Woodson and more recently Charles Tillman have all looked very good after age 30. (And speaking of the Bears, how about that 34-year-old Brian Urlacher?)

Also I think players slow down as a function of the wear & tear on their bodies, not just chronological age. That is why, to me, Troy Polamalu is in some respects an "old" 31. Surely his basic conditioning is still superb. But, but: over the years he has been a human highlight reel by constantly pushing the boundaries of what's physically possible, and I think that perhaps that style of play takes its toll ... sometimes even over the course of a single season. (Note that Troy has played in 3 Super Bowls & has not really had a standout game in any of them. He maxes himself out getting the team there.) So maybe the best-case is that this year, he misses the midseason but is wired up for prime time by postseason.

In general, the Steelers have been phasing out their older stars gradually. Hines Ward & James Farrior are now gone; this year might be the last for Keisel and some others. We'll see how the transition goes for the rest of the season, and whether or not a good balance has been struck.

So I have an idea...
Vote for the party that started all this fiscal mess in the first place so they can come back and finish the job. The party that has stood in the way of and refused to work with all Democrats for the last 4 years. The party that would rather see this Country suffer than allow our voted President to be a President. The party that vowed 4 years ago to do whatever it took to bring Obama down. The party that was responsible for my economic layoff in 2008 and the inevitable foreclosure on my house that same year. The party that believes it is perfectly okay to routinely lie to its constituency while looking them in the eye. The party that does not believe that America is for ALL Americans, not just the rich ones. The party that had no problem with hijacking our country's credit rating in the World just so that rich people could pay less taxes while everyone else was suffering. The party that has issues and problems with womens' health issues, gay citizens, 47% of it's population, the disabled, the unemployed, and the color of one's skin.
And I have a dream....
That dream is for not one single American citizen to ever vote another Republican into office ever again. It's a really great dream. And that is something that the Republicans have not figured how to take from me yet. My dreams.

Ryan, I appreciate your analysis here and I agree that the current strategy of Obama seems plain old desperate and not all that Presidential.

However, Obama has the vote of the entire world in a landslide right now and Obama has won back the respect that Bush lost and the world does not want Mitt.
http://www.care2.com/causes/obama-wins-by-a-landslide-if-the-world-could...

The Republicans have admitted that they are fighting Obama in order to make him into a one term presidency. They are hurting the citizens while doing this. I will not vote for a Republican due to this. I also will not vote for a high priest Mormon for the Oval Office. Mormons are too fundamentalists I believe. ..

In addition Mitt Romney lied 35 times in the first debate and has done in all three debates and I sure do not trust him. I will be sticking with Obama as I know he is very much Presidential when this too long election finally ends.
Cjk - What's wrong with England, France & Germany?  Is there anyone you like? Maybe N. Korea?

"And following some rest, I would wish that both men tackle the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy."

Good god, the families w/o heat,electricity nor homes are not resting! Where do you people come from....

Corporations - which give people jobs - is a far better option to have at the helm than a mindset that says we need a wasteful, bigger government that hypocritically bites the hand that feeds it. I am not rich - not even middle class - but I smell injustice when I see it and the left's stupidity of "let us take your money and spend it, for we know better how to do that than you do" is plain dumb. Free will giving is by far the more sensible way to meet the needs of those who are sincerely poor. America is a full of generous citizens, but demanding the money (aka taxes) of hard working people under the guise of "pay your fair share" will cripple this blessed nation. Hands off what is due to those who work hard for it! Let them decide by their own will how much they will give to help others in need. That is a far better way to govern a country.
I am praying, but it is not for an Obama victory.
Cjk could you please back up your point?  Because if I have read correctly it is not the case.  None of these nations have attacked us formally.

Nearly every generation has inherited debt, its how it works. People buy our debt because they know its a good investment, because it gets paid back.

Obama faced raising that deficit or watching a lot of people suffer miserably, he made the right choice, you need to give him the eight years, the problems were massive when he took office.

George Bush inherited a $300 billion surplus with a booming economy and turned it into a $1.2T deficit.

Obama inherited a $1.2T deficit with the worst recession since 1929. Now the economy is rebounding and the deficit is $1.1T.

Obama pledges to reduce deficits in a balanced way that does not pile all burdens on students, retirees, and minimum wage workers.

Romney's tax cuts to the rich, does not help the deficit. He wants to increase military spending, and repeal the estate tax. The estate tax literally affects only those with $7 millions worth of estate.

If you think Romney is better for the deficit you are in for a rude surprise.
you dont say why, as in, what facts has mitt given you to make you think he will or can. bush made the exact same promises. promises are cheap.

Doubtful.

He wouldn't have won the Republican nomination if he had written or said anything else about the GM/Chrysler bailout.
